Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Laser Range Scanner for Intraoperative Neurosurgical Navigation

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with eight patients undergoing neurosurgery at a single institution.

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they required neurosurgery for various clinical presentations.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention involved using an LRS to acquire intraoperative cortical surface descriptions, which were then registered with preoperative magnetic resonance tomograms.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the mean feature alignment error between LRS and magnetic resonance surfaces, measured intraoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not specified.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with eight patients undergoing neurosurgery at a single institution.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Successful textured LRS surface acquisition was achieved for all eight patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean feature alignment error was 1.7 Â± 0.8 mm, indicating accurate registration between intraoperative and preoperative data.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported during the study.
